end.title: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
end.brief_description: While many people believe Walt Disney’s Snow White and The Seven Dwarfs (1937) was the first animated feature, Lotte Reiniger’s The Adventures of Prince Achmed precedes the Disney film by over a decade.

constellations_primary.name: Shadowplay and spookiness
constellations_primary.description: Silhouettes and shadows scare up some of the most sinister creatures in cinema and videogames.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

constellations_other.name: Storytelling through shadow play
constellations_other.description: Shadow play has brought stories to life for thousands of years and is still used today.

links.description: Prince Achmed is the first-ever feature animation using cut-out silhouette puppetry. Its creator, Lotte Reiniger, began telling stories using shadow puppetry from a young age, a creative practice that influenced her animation style.

links.description: Woody and Buzz engage in a shadow puppet contest. As in Ivan Tsarevich, computer animation is used to represent the analogue form of shadow play. Renowned for technological innovation, the Toy Story franchise builds narratives around nostalgia for simpler times.

links.description: Wayang shadow puppetry is a traditional method of storytelling originating in Java and India, dating back centuries. Jumaadi’s installation draws on this tradition to tell the true story of a deaf musician who teaches his blind son the art of wayang kulit.
